As l have said, he was perhaps too impatient of all ob- scure thinking, from not considering that on cer· ’ tain subjects, necessarily in their substance, and on the skirts of all subjecte, obscurity and vagne- ness, difficulty and uncertainty, are inherent, and must therefore appear in their treatment. Men who rejoiced in making clear things obscure, and plain things the reverse, he could not abide‚ and spoke with some contempt of those who were original merely from their standing on their heads, and tall from walking upon stilts. As you have truly said, his character mellowed and toned down in his later years, without in any way losing its own individualiry, and its clear, vigorous, unflinch- ing perception of and addiction to principles.
